AI_QUALITY_FAILURES.reasoning: The ATLAS chat transcript is mostly intake/triage and does not show the AI giving incorrect technical guidance or making promises that were not followed. The substantive troubleshooting and decisions were handled by human agents.

AI_WALL_LOOPING.reasoning: The customer was able to reach human agents quickly after ticket creation, and the thread shows ongoing human engagement rather than repeated AI prompts or inability to reach a person.

IGNORING_CONTEXT.reasoning: Support initially anchored on an incorrect Salesforce opportunity link and diagnosis, requiring the customer to correct them. Later, support suggested browser cache/cookie troubleshooting even though internal context indicated the issue was likely automation/onboarding/email-mapping related (not a client-side cache issue). This created unnecessary back-and-forth and delayed addressing the real root cause.
evidence: Customer: "This is the correct Salesforce opportunity: https://trilogy-sales.lightning.force.com/lightning/r/Opportunity/006Ih000004fwJXIAY/view" (after support referenced a different opportunity earlier).
Support (Alexandr): "Could you please ask the user to clear cache and cookies, restart the browser and relogin to support portal and try again"
Internal (Raymond): "No kind of refresh is needed after updating the gsheet. There is no caching for the gsheet anywhere."
Customer (after following cache advice): "I cleared the cache, installed Google Chrome, tested with Chrome, and still get the same error. Tried different computers as well."

RESPONSE_DELAYS.reasoning: No clear 3+ calendar day gaps between a customer message and a support response are visible. Responses generally occur within hours to ~1 day.

PREMATURE_CLOSURE.reasoning: The ticket shows continued troubleshooting through to a stated fix deployment; there is no indication it was closed while the customer still had an unanswered request.

P1_SEV1_MISHANDLING.reasoning: The issue was marked Urgent and was blocking first-time activation (customer could not add any devices due to 0 licenses/devices). Despite being a backend automation/onboarding defect, handling included long 'hold' periods and generic client-side troubleshooting (cache/cookies) after automation was said to be fixed, rather than immediate escalation/owner-driven investigation. Root cause ultimately was a backend case-sensitivity bug, reinforcing that earlier standard troubleshooting was not appropriately prioritized.
evidence: Customer impact: "The customer is unable to add any devices... I need the licenses activated so they can proceed."
System action: "Placing on hold for 12 hour(s)" (multiple times: 2025-10-07 and 2025-10-07).
Support (Alexandr) after customer still blocked: "clear cache and cookies... try from another browser" (generic troubleshooting for what became a backend defect).
Internal (Raymond): "it is a case sensitivity issue with the automation. will fix it in few minutes."
Resolution note: "This has now been resolved." (indicating platform-side bug, not a user/browser issue).
